Description.2: • Description text
• Improvisers get a suggestion and one at a time step forward and deliver a joke or pun with the format below.

Example.5: • The bartender says, we don't serve bananas here.
Example.6: • The 185 bananas say, what? are we too unappealing for you?
Example.11: • The bartender says, we don't serve bananas here.

Description.2: • Two improvisers take the stage.
Description.3: • A suggestion is given.
Description.4: • They strike a pose then hold it and wait.
Description.5: • After 60 seconds the teacher calls start and the scene begins.

Purpose.2: • In the beginning you'll be thinking of many different ideas and dropping them, thinking about the other person, and shifting your posture slightly.
Purpose.3: • As you near the 60 second mark that panic will settle and you'll have nothing but a general idea of the dynamic between you and your partner.
Purpose.4: • By the time the scene starts you should be ready to listen intently to your scene partner.

Sources.2: • How to be the Greatest Improviser on Earth by Will Hines - p. 22

Description.2: • An ensemble member comes up with an unusual product by taking an ordinary item and giving it an unusual trait
Description.3: <ul>
Description.5: • A car that changes color based on it's surroundings.
Description.6: • A refrigerator that is also a radio.
Description.8: • The ensemble works together to create an advertising campaign for an unusual product.
Description.9: • They will come up with a name, slogan, target demographic, celebrity spokesperson, jingle, etc...
Description.10: • All the elements of the product should complement each other.
Description.11: • No matter the idea, the entire group must support and yes and it.

Example.3: • Improviser 2: "Yeah! We could have Meryl Streep as the spokesperson. She could talk about how she disappears into her roles like this car disappears into it's surroundings."
Example.4: • Improviser 3: "Yeah! She could start off the commercial as Julia Child and then finish as Margaret Thatcher."
Example.5: • Improviser 4: "We could sell it to criminals! If they're being chased by the police, they can blend into their surroundings to hide."
Example.6: • Improviser 3: "We could take helicopter footage of a police chase and suddenly, the car disappears, blending into the highway!"
Example.7: • Improviser 2: "When you don't want to be seen, this is your machine."
Example.8: • Improviser 4: "Great slogan! *Starts to sing* This car's named after a lizard that can hide, buy this car and camouflage your ride!"

Purpose.1: Used as an exercise, the ensemble will...
Purpose.4: • Strengthen their ability to listen, yes and, and utilize give and take.

Sources.2: • The Upright Citizens Brigade Comedy Improv Manual (second edition) by Matt Besser, Ian Roberts, and Matt Walsh - p. 302

Instructions.3: • On the count of three all players strike a pose and make a noise as an alien, a tiger, or a cow.
Instructions.5: • Alien: Hold your two index fingers up to your head like antennae and say "Bleep blorp!"
Instructions.6: • Tiger: Throw your hands out like your clawing and roar.
Instructions.7: • Cow: Hold your hands up to you stomach with your fingers sticking out like udders and say "Mooo!"
Instructions.10: • You can play with the intention of everyone trying to land on the same pose or eliminate the minority group each time until there is only one or two players left.

Purpose.2: • This is a fun easy way to warm up. Great for children or beginners.

Description.2: • Two improvisers take the stage and a basic suggestion is given.
Description.3: • They perform a scene where each sentence must begin with a word that starts with the next consecutive letter of the alphabet.
Description.4: • They can go from A to Z and end the scene there or restart at A and continue until a more traditional edit is made.

Example.3: • Improviser 1: Alright can you turn that off?
Example.4: • Improviser 2: Boy it sure is loud! What did you say?
Example.5: • Improviser 1: Can you turn off the alarm please?
Example.6: • Improviser 2: Didn't hear you. The alarm is too loud.

Purpose.2: • This excercise privides a fun challenge for improvisers and forces them to listen and think quickly.

Variations.2: • You could play with more than two players.
Variations.3: • You could have the audience choose the starting letter.
Variations.4: • You could play it as an elimination game where people get out if they mess up or take too long to respond.

Description.2: • Players stand in a circle and snap, clap, or pat a rhythm.
Description.3: • Everyone chants together in rhythm: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap.
Description.4: • The first player raps a line, establishing the rhyming word.
Description.5: • Everyone chants together between each line.
Description.6: • The next player raps a line setting up an obvious rhyme for the last word of the previous line but then chooses a non rhyming word to end the line.
Description.7: • The next player in the circle uses the last word of the previous line to set up an obvious rhyme but then again doesn't go for it.
Description.8: • Continue the pattern as long as your group likes!

Example.2: • Group: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap
Example.3: • Player 1: I sure would like to eat a snack!
Example.4: • Player 2: (thinking of the rhyme pack) I always stick together with my wolf crew!
Example.5: • Group: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap
Example.6: • Player 3: (thinking of the rhyme dew) I love the grass in the morning covered in wet!
Example.7: • Group: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap
Example.8: • Player 4: (thinking of the rhyme debt) I have bag credit because I'm in finance bad!
Example.9: • Group: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap

Variations.2: • Have the next person finish your line with the non-rhyming word.
Variations.5: • Group: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap
Variations.6: • Player 1: I sure would like to eat a snack!
Variations.7: • Group: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap
Variations.8: • Player 2: (thinking of the rhyme pack) I always stick together with my wolf...
Variations.10: • Group: bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap bad rap _ bad rap _ bad rap

Tips.2: • Try to set up the next person with an easy word to rhyme. Single syllable words are usually safe.
Tips.3: • As soon as you hear the person before you's end word, think of a rhyme, then build up to it and pick a different word at the last second.
Tips.4: • Synonyms are usually the way to ge, but a curveball can be fun too.

Description.2: • Two teams of 3-4 players will face off in a pseudo rap battle.
Description.3: • Each team has a leader who sets up rhymes and supporters who try to complete the rhyme in time with a beat.
Description.4: • Instruct the audience to make a buzzer sound if the team fails to complete the rhyme in a way that makes sense or is too off beat.
Description.5: • To start each round, the host will get a one word suggestion.
Description.6: • The two leaders will go back and fourth trying to set up their team to complete their rhyme with the suggested word.
Description.7: • If the support players fail to complete the rhyme appropriately the leader is eliminated and rotates to the back to become a supporter and a new leader steps forward, which starts a new round.
Description.8: • The team who won the previous round will go first in the next round.
Description.9: • A team loses when all their members have been eliminated as the leader.

Example.3: • Team 1 Leader: Little kids at recess, they love to...
Example.5: • Team 2 Leader: I sure don't curse, those aren't words that I...
Example.7: • Team 1 Leader: I don't know where I am, I don't know which...
Example.8: • Team 1 Support: ... uhhh... Oh! WAY!(way too late off beat)
Example.10: • Team 1 rotates and a new round beings.

Purpose.2: • This game is great for practicing rhyming, getting in a rhyming mindset, and setting up others to finish rhymes.
Purpose.3: • It's a great warm-up or show opener.

Tips.2: • Really bring that energy and spirit of competion to this game. Feel free to dis the other team or act like their rhymes are whack.
Tips.3: • The host should ask the audience for one or two syllable words unless the performers are very skilled at rhyming.
Tips.4: • If it is helpful a leader can do an act out as part or their set up.
Tips.5: • The beat can be played by a percussion, a looping backing track, or by having the performers snap, clap, or pat. But a track or percussionist is preferred for a live performance.

Description.2: • Improvisers circle up and snap, clap, or pat a beat.
Description.3: • The game starts with a chant in rhythm: Dada da da dada da!
Description.4: • Repeat the chant 2-4 times at the start of the game.
Description.5: • The first improviser will rap a line ending with an easily rhymable word.
Description.6: • Repeat the chant once after each line.
Description.7: • Going around the circle, the next 3 improvisers will rap a line that ends by rhyming with the first improviser.
Description.8: • Other members in the circle will listen closely and try to predict and say the rhyming word at the same time.
Description.9: • After the initial line and the three rhyming lines, the chant is repeated 2-4 and the next person in the circle raps a new line with a new easily rhymable word and the pattern repeats.

Example.4: • Player 1: I just put on my brand new SHOES!
Example.9: • Player 3: Wanna be a member? Better pay your-
Example.12: • Player 4: My main man Scott on the ones and-
Example.16: • Then a new round starts with the next member in the circle.

Purpose.2: • This is a great group warm up and useful for practicing rhyming and bringing high energy.

Tips.2: • Really bring that Beastie Boys vibe and energy.
Tips.3: • As soon as you hear the rhyme word quickly think of as many rhyming words as you can to have ready to go.

Description.2: • Players form a circle and designate someone to start as Big Booty.
Description.3: • The rest of the players starting to the left of big booty will be assigned a number, starting at one and counting up.
Description.4: • To start the game the players will all start patting, snapping, or clapping a moderate rhythm.
Description.5: • All together everyone chats "Awwww snap! Big Booty Big Booty Big Booty!"
Description.6: • Big Booty will start by saying "Big Booty number #" in rhythm, filling in the # with one of the players numbers.
Description.7: • That number player will respond with their own number and then another number with the format "number #(their number) number #(a new number)".
Description.8: • They can also send it back to big booty like this: "number #(their number) Big Booty".
Description.9: • If a player messes up by saying their own number, not realizing they've been called, or taking too long everyone chants says together: "awww snap!" then they go to the end of the line and everyone who was after them moves down a number.

Example.2: • Everyone: Aww snap! Big Booty Big Booty Big Booty!
Example.11: • Player 7 goes to the end(the right of big booty) and everyone from number 8 and higher moves down a number.

Purpose.2: • This game makes a great warm-up, or ice-breaker.
Purpose.3: • Players of this game need to be in the moment and listening, ready to react and respond when called up.

Description.2: • The group forms a circle and everyone begins patting their legs in rhythm and chanting "zoom-ba zoom-ba".
Description.3: • One player will start by saying(in rhythm) "bunny bunny" while making two pairs of bunny ears with their hands and pointing them at themself.
Description.4: • That same player with then repeat the above step but point the bunny ears and someone else in the circle.
Description.5: • That person who was pointed to will repeat the above two steps pointing to a new person, and we pass it around the circle.
Description.6: • While any player is doing the bunny ears part, the two players on either side of them should face towards them and wave their arms left and right chanting "ticky tocky ticky tocky"!
Description.7: • This game can go as long as it needs to or until it feels like we've exhausted the fun or novelty of it.
Description.8: • Optionally the group can slowly ramp up the speed and end it once it becomes to fast to continue.

Purpose.2: • Great warm up to just prepare to be silly.

Description.2: • Several improvisers form a back line.
Description.3: • One improviser steps forward, they will be the chameleon.
Description.4: • One at a time improviser step off the back line to initiate a short scene with the chameleon.
Description.5: • They should enter with a strong character choice.
Description.6: • The chameleon has to match their character choice and the two do a peas in a pod scene.
Description.7: • After a few short scenes, a new improviser from the back line becomes the chameleon.

Sources.2: • The Upright Citizens Brigade Comedy Improv Manual (second edition) by Matt Besser, Ian Roberts, and Matt Walsh - p. 178

Description.2: • This is a game for 4+ improvisers where each walk-on will have to try and guess the suggestions and then convey them to the next person using only miming and gibberish.
Description.3: • All but one improviser leaves the room and the remaining improviser and/or host get three suggestions.
Description.4: • The suggestions are for an occupation, weapon, and location.
Description.5: • The scene starts when the starting improviser mimes killing an improviser from the backline with the murder weapon. The murdered improviser should lay on the floor and become a dead body.
Description.6: • Teach the audience to shout a phrase like, Oh no! There's been a murder!, each time a murder happens to summon in the next improviser.
Description.7: • Each improviser who enters the scene will assume the standing improviser has murdered the dead person or persons on the floor and accuse them (using only gibberish mind you).
Description.8: • The standing improviser then mimes the three suggestions in order.
Description.9: • The guessing improviser should give some indication that they think they know what the suggestion is before the miming improviser moves on to the next one.
Description.10: • Once the guessing improviser understands all three suggestions they then mime killing the other improviser with what they think is the murder weapon.
Description.11: • This cycle continues until all improviser have had their turn.
Description.12: • At the end we call scene and the host goes down the line and each improviser says what they think the suggestions were.
Description.13: • Instruct the audience to clap or make a buzzer sound based on if the improviser is correct or not.

Tips.2: • Use the acronym O.W.L. to remember the order of the suggestions being acted out.
Tips.3: • Really play up the gibberish and be expressive. The scene gets awkward if the improvisers are too quiet or not animated enough.
Tips.4: • The guessers shouldn't make the miming improviser spend too much time on each suggestion, as soon as you think you have an idea of what they might be doing give them the go-ahead to switch to the next suggestion. We don't want the scene to go on too long and it's funnier if the suggestions get lost along the way than if they stay the same the whole time.

Description.2: • Two improvisers start a scene and a third acts as a host.
Description.3: • The host will ring a bell or say a phrase like change! or new decision! periodically after a line of dialogue has been said.
Description.4: • The improviser who said that last line of dialogue will have to say a new line of dialogue to replace it.

Example.5: • Improviser 2: I want a whole cake to myself.
Example.7: • Improviser 2: I want you to love me again!

Tips.2: • Try to heighten each time you are made to change a line of dialogue and go for a drastic change on the third changed line.
Tips.3: • As the host, utilize the rule of three most of the time, only occasionally making the improvisers change only one line of dialogue or making them change many lines in a long run of changes.

Description.2: • Three improvisers take a seat or stand on stage.
Description.3: • A host welcomes the crowd to this special event where we have a panel of experts and gets a suggestion for the topic on which they are experts.
Description.4: • Optionally the host can give the improvisers a chance to introduce themselves as their characters
Description.5: • The host fields questions from the audience and lets the characters go down the line and answer them.
Description.6: • The host can make some observations or inferences about the characters in between their answers and questions but shouldn't take up too much time talking themself.

Purpose.2: • Improvisers are able to make up a character and explore their perspective without worrying about other elements of scene work.
Purpose.3: • Improviers will have to listen to their scene partners and make decisions that are distinct from them.

Tips.2: • Answers to questions should last too long, this isn't a monologue.
Tips.3: • Improvisers need to make sure their characters are very distinct from each other and have unique perspectives on the topic.
Tips.4: • Commit fully to their characters or this game will get boring real quick.
Tips.5: • The host should moderate the amount of questions based on how long they take to get through each character, usually 2-4 questions is best.
Tips.6: • Let a different character answer first in each round of questions.

Description.2: • Improvisers form a circle.
Description.3: • One improviser will cross the circle to approach another improviser and initiate a 3-4 line scene with them.
Description.4: • The initiating improviser will make a strong character choice, embracing the physicality, characteristics, and voice of that character as they approach and initiate.
Description.5: • The improviser who was approached will take on the same physicality, characteristics, and voice as the approaching improviser and respond to their initiation.
Description.6: • They should take on the same characteristics even if the approaching improviser makes it clear in their initiating line that they are not the same type of character(see example below).
Description.7: • After 3-4 lines total the inititating improviser will take the place of the other improviser, who will now approach someone else in the circle as a new character and initate a new 3-4 lines scene.
Description.8: • Go until everyone has had a turn to both initiate and respond to an initiation.

Example.4: • Improviser 1: *approaching hunched over, walking with a cane, speaking with an eldery voice* "When I was your age little timmy, baseballs only costs a nickle!"
Example.5: • Improviser 2: *taking on the same elderly physicality and voice* "Well gee wilikers Mr. Griffordson I can't get a toothpick for that price these days."
Example.8: • Both characters match the character and perspective
Example.10: • Improviser 1: *approaching as a twitchy little gremlin* "Ehhhh! Grimble, I'm hungry for human flesh!"
Example.11: • Improviser 2: *taking on the same physicality* "Yes! I want a skin muffin and a venti blood frappe!"

Purpose.2: • You get to play a variety of characters in a short amount of time.
Purpose.3: • You get to practice changing yourself based on someone else's actions/initation.

Sources.2: • How to be the Greatest Improviser on Earth by Will Hines - p. 41

Instructions.2: • An audience volunteer is selected to tell the story of their day, or alternatively you could ask for a specific type of story.
Instructions.5: • For a theme show: your craziest New Years Eve story
Instructions.7: • The interviewer or backline should feel free to ask clarifying questions or to ask for more details if the story teller is a little more timid.
Instructions.8: • After the interview, the ensemble will perform this persons day.
Instructions.9: • The goal is not to recreate the story as is, the goal is to use the characters, ideas, situations, and general structure from the story to create a fun scene.

Purpose.2: • The interview section will force improvisers to listen intently.
Purpose.3: • This is a good exercise to teach the basics of premise based long form, like listening for specifcs in an opening and bringing them into a scene.

Tips.2: • Members from the backline should feel free to become inanimate objects in sections of the scene where there are no secondary characters present.
Tips.3: • Don't be overly indulgent in the interview section, we don't want to alienate the audience member by constantly interupting them for jokes. The improvisers can be funny during the scene.
Tips.5: • It will also make the whole setup and scene take a really long time.

Description.2: • Improvisers get a suggestion and one at a time deliver a pun or joke as if it were gossip about one of the other improvisers in the circle.
Description.3: • This pun game is a little more conversational. Improvisers deliver their puns to each other instead of directly to the audience.
Description.4: • This pun game is also very character focused. Improvisers should put on their valley girl or stuck-up kind of gossipy character.

Example.6: • Brad: Hey tina, did you hear about Greg?
Example.7: • Tina: No Brad oh em jeee what about him?
Example.8: • Brad: I heard that he contracted Chev-VD
Example.9: • Tina: Oh no I hope it's not carmydia!
Example.13: • Greg: Hey Brad can I talk to you please?
Example.14: <liBrad: Oh my gah Greg, yes what's wrong?li>
Example.15: • Greg: I have to break up with Shirley.
Example.17: • Greg: Last night she got drunk off en-gin & tonics and kissed my dad!
Example.18: • Brad: Oh no gross! Kick her to the curb!

Tips.2: • Really play up and commit to your character choice.
Tips.3: • Normally in pun games, one improviser steps up and delivers their pun then returns to the back line. For this one it's more conversations and it's okay for each bit to be almost a qucik little scene.
Tips.4: • It's also okay to address multiple improvisers at once or to call someone in the group out(within the game).

Description.2: • The host sets up the game. Two improvisers will perform an entire story in just one minute. They can riff a little about how movies today are too long, people don't have long attention spans or whatever.
Description.3: • The host then gets a suggestion. It could be an existing story or movie title, a made up title, a genre, or any basic suggestion.
Description.4: • The two improviers then perform that scene, trying to create the entire story in one minute. The host will time them and call scene at one minute.
Description.5: • Then the host will point out that it's still too long and set them up to do the same scene in half the time.
Description.6: • This pattern continues doing the same scene in half the time going from 60 to 30 to 15 to 7 to 3 to 1 second(s).
Description.7: • Each time the scene is replayed it's distilled and/or sped up further until the final one second scene.

Tips.2: • Try to move around the stage and use object work to help you remember the flow of what happens in the original scene.
Tips.3: • It probably won't be an extremely compelling narrative but try to have a beginning, middle, and end.

Description.2: • One player starts a scene as a realtor preparing an open house.
Description.3: • Shortly after a few guests(usually 2-3) knock on the door and are welcomed to view the house.
Description.4: • The realtor shows the guests around and one by one the guests ask questions about the absurdities of the house.
Description.5: • These questions involve a bit of scene painting of absurd things we don't already know about the house.
Description.6: • It is the realtors job to logically justify these absurd features of the house.

Example.2: • Guest: Excuse me, could you tell me a bit about this rusty blood stained trap door here in the floor?
Example.3: • Realtor: Ah certainly! One of this home's primary security features. There is a ferocious blood thirsty beast underneath that door. If ever you're in danger from a home intruder, you need only pull that lever.

Description.2: • Players form a circle.
Description.3: • Players think of a random word and raise their hand.
Description.4: • The first two players to do so will count down from three and say their word at the same time.
Description.5: • Everyone now tries to think of a word the connects the two previous words.
Description.6: • You can't repeat a word that's already been used in a round.
Description.7: • The first two to think of a connecting word raise their hand then count down from three and say their words at the same time.
Description.8: • The goal is for the two players to say the same word at the same time and the round ends when that happens.

Example.3: • Any player: Car! (at the same time) Any other player: Peanut!
Example.4: • A leading player, teacher, or anyone can repeat the two words for anyone who didn't catch them.
Example.7: • Any player: Shell! (at the same time) Any other player: Inside!
Example.10: • Any player: Clam! (at the same time) Any other player: Crab!
Example.13: • Any player: Seafood! (at the same time) Any other player: Seafood!
Example.14: • Celebrate accordingly as decided by your group!

Purpose.2: • Played with speed this can be a good get out of your head game.
Purpose.3: • This game helps establish a group mind, helping improvisers see how each other thinks and makes connections.

Tips.3: • Try and keep the speed up between guesses.
Tips.4: • Don't be precious trying to think of the perfect connection, just go for it.

Variations.2: • You can play it around the circle rather than by raising your hand to volunteer.
Variations.3: • You can play speed mode where you don't take any time between guessers and imediate start counting down from three after each set of guesses.
Variations.4: • You playing in pairs or a larger group.

Description.2: • This format is without any real structure.
Description.3: • A suggestion can be gotten at the top or the set can begin completely organically.
Description.4: • If a suggestion is gotten at the top, that will inspire the initiation for the first scene.
Description.5: • Each scene will be initiated based off something organically pulled from the improvisers mind, or from an element from the scene the preceeded it.
Description.6: • Improvisers can use any support moves or edits available to them to play the scenes before moving on to the next.
Description.7: • The scenes do not have to have any through line or connections.

Purpose.2: • Doing organic sets is a great way to practice finding and playing game organically.

Tips.2: • Try to add variety to your scenes by varying them in length, number of performers per scene and energy level.

Description.2: • One or Two volunteers from the audience are selected to come stand or sit on stage.
Description.3: • Get a suggestion.
Description.4: • Two improvisers perform a scene.
Description.5: • Every now and then the improvisers will tap a volunteer on the shoulder and the volunteer will supply a random word.
Description.6: • The improvisor will then have to justify that word as if they had said it themself.

Example.3: • Improviser 2: Yeah, on a day like this I really feel like... *taps volunteer*
Example.5: • Improviser 2: Scooping up some mud and just making some mud pies with you bro.
Example.6: • Improviser 1: Ah! That sounds amazing! I... *taps volunteer*
Example.8: • Improviser 1: Grapes, I think grapes are the snack we should bring.
Example.9: • Improviser 2: You're so thoughtful. You know I love grapes because... *taps volunteer*
Example.11: • Improviser 2: Sniff, the sniff aroma of grapes pleases me.

Tips.2: • Give the audience members a chance to practice before you really start the scene.
Tips.3: • Instruct the audience memebers to just blurt out a random word, don't try to make it fit in the context of the scene.

Description.2: • This is a game for two improvisers.
Description.3: • A volunteer from the audience is invited to sit center stage.
Description.4: • The two improvisers conduct a brief interview of the audience member. Get their name, family, pets, occupation, hobbies, etc...
Description.5: • Instruct the audience member that whoever they are looking at during the song has to be singing, they can switch back and forth between who they are looking at as much as they want, and to use and abuse this power.
Description.6: • The music comes in and who ever is being looked at must serenade the audience member.
Description.7: • The improviers will need to listen intently while the other is singing so they can continue any lines are are interupted with a switch.

Tips.2: • If you get switched to mid word or phrase, do your best to finish that word or phrase.
Tips.3: • Use the persons name often. It's a good reset or start of a line or verse.
Tips.4: • Better yet if you can set up rhymes with their name.

Description.2: • Before the show have audience members write sentences on strips of paper.
Description.3: • These can be random silly sentences, song lyrics, lines from movies, pick-up lines, or anything else!
Description.4: • Set up a basic scene with a suggestion or use one of the variations below, then pass out 3-4 sentence strips to the improvisers.
Description.5: • The improvisers will perform a scene, occasionally pulling out a sentence strip and reading it as their dialogue.
Description.6: • The improvisers must then justify the line they just said.
Description.7: • The scene continues until the host edits, usually after they've used all their sentence strips.

Example.2: • Improviser 1: I love the sound of rain outside.
Example.7: • Improviser 1: There's spinach in your teeth! It's making me sick!

Purpose.2: • A great exercise in listening and justification.
Purpose.3: • Usually a real crowd pleaser, audience members are excited to hear the dialogue they wrote, and it's always funny to see the cast react to the out of no where line they've just said and try to justify it.

Tips.2: • It's usually best to just pull out a strip and read it without any prompting like "My grampa always told me..." or "That makes me think of the time..."
Tips.3: • Don't read the strip immediately, give the scene a few lines back and forth to establish the base reality and a bit of the character first.
Tips.4: • You can have someone(not someone who will be performing in these scenes) pre read the sentences to make sure there isn't anything problematic.
Tips.5: • Either way make sure the improvisers know they can omit anything from their strip they deem problematic or are uncomfortable saying.

Variations.4: • Have the audience members write pick-up lines on the strips.
Variations.5: • Designate 2-3 improvisers to be the ones the pickup-ees and the others will get the sentence strips and be the pickup-ers
Variations.6: • You can say they're at a bar or get a suggestion for where these pick-ups are happening.
Variations.7: • The pickup-ers will take turns shooting their shot, coming up to talk to the pickup-ees, delivering their pick-up lines, and getting rejected.
Variations.8: • It's fun if by the end, at least one of the pick-up lines works and that pair leave together.
Variations.12: • Get an audience member to volunteer their name, the improvisers will be attending their funeral.
Variations.13: • We designate the front center stage to be where the open casket is located.
Variations.14: • The improvisers will approach in groups of 2 or 3, mix and matching performers each time they come back.
Variations.15: • They will be playing the dead persons, friends, family, co workers, etc... Talking and sharing stories about the person using their sentence strips as inspiration.
Variations.17: • These are just couple variations we play, there are infinite possibilities so make up and experiment with your own.

Description.2: • A simple tagline is discovered through a scene or suggestion.
Description.3: • Then the music will come in and the improvisers will sing a song with four parts.
Description.4: • In a front facing tagline song each verse starts with the Tagline.
Description.5: • In a back facing tagline song each verse ends with the tagline, so you know before you start what rhyme you need to set up.

Structure.4: • Bridge that does not include the tagline
Structure.6: • Optionally: repeat the tagline for a big finish!

Tips.2: • If the tagline ends with an easy rhyme, go for a back facing tagline
Tips.3: • If the tagline seems hard to rhyme with, start your verse with the tagline.
Tips.4: • Other singers can sing the tagline on each verse even if it's not their verse. Especially at the end.

Description.2: • One improviser initiates a scene with some sort of phyical activity.
Description.3: • The activity should be something that can be continued throughout the scene like washing dishes, folding laundry, decorating for a party, etc...
Description.4: • A second improviser should join the scene and the activity.
Description.5: • They must then perform the scene without speaking about the activity at hand.

Purpose.2: • Usually you don't talk about doing dishes while you're doing dishes, or most other mundane activities.
Purpose.4: • This exercise will also help you build your environment and keep the scene dynamic without getting stuck talking about something uninteresting.

Sources.2: • The Upright Citizens Brigade Comedy Improv Manual (second edition) by Matt Besser, Ian Roberts, and Matt Walsh - p. 36

Description.2: • One improviser is selected to be the taxi driver and guesser. They leave the room while the host or participating improvisers get suggestions.
Description.3: • 3-6 other improvisers will be the cab riders. They will get suggestions for distinct characters to play.
Description.4: • They can be cartoon characters, celebrities, innanimate objects, animals or anything else that can be played for comedic effect.
Description.5: • Once all the suggestions are gotten, we can call back in the driver to start the scene.
Description.6: • They'll mime starting off their day and soon pick up the first rider.
Description.7: • The rider will give hints to the driver based on their behavior and answers to the cab driver's questions.
Description.8: • Once the driver has an idea who they think the person might be they can begin guessing.
Description.9: • Once they guess correctly they can drop off the rider and pick up the next.

Purpose.2: • This is a fun game to play with improvisers of all skill levels.
Purpose.3: • The driver must listen and pay close attention to the character to try and guess who they are.
Purpose.4: • New improvisers are forced to step outside themself and play a character.

Tips.2: • The rider's hints should start out relatively vague and get more obvious over time so as not to give it away too quickly, or spend too much time on one character.
Tips.3: • If it seems like the driver really can't get it, feel free, after some time, to just give it up with a rhyme - "You really don't know me? It rhymes with picky pouse!"
Tips.4: • If you're playing with only 2-3 passengers, or a particularly good guesser, feel free to give them a secondary characteristic after their character like...
Tips.8: • A thunderstorm with a crush on John Cena
Tips.9: • A praying mantis who is obsessed with reality tv

Description.2: • One player is the narrator of the story and sits or stands on stage miming like they are writing a story on a typewriter.
Description.3: • The narrator speaks aloud what he is "writing".
Description.4: • Improvisers will enter the scene to play the characters the narrator mentions and begin playing the scene normally.
Description.5: • The narrator can give and take focus at any time.

Example.2: • Narrator: The mystery of the missing moose. Chapter one, the forest sleeps. A cool chill hung in the early morning air as Park Ranger Mitchel and his young apprentice Carl began their morning forest inspection hike.
Example.3: • Two improvisers step out miming preparing for their walk.
Example.4: • Carl: It's freezing out here Mr. Mitchel. Maybe we go back and sit around the fire until it warms up a bit.
Example.5: • Ranger Mitchel: I'm sure everything's fine Carl. But it's our responsibility to make sure all the forest creatures are safe from anyone who would do them harm.
Example.6: • Narrator: But everything wasn't fine in the forest that day, and it wouldn't be long before the ranger noticed something out of the ordinary.
Example.7: • Ranger Mitchel: Oh my god. Freeze boy.
Example.8: • Carl: Why? What is it Mr. Mitchel?
Example.9: • Ranger Mitchel: You see that? It's a moose egg. Not usualy for them to be left alone like that. Momma's gotta be nearby.
Example.10: • Narrator: A large, brown, and furry egg lay nestled in a bed of pine needles surrounded by trees in every direction. A trail of crimson staining the forest floor lay before them leading into the thickest brush of the woods.
Example.11: • Carl: Wait... Mr. Mitchel. Is that blood?

Tips.2: • Be sure improvisers are using give and take to share the spotlight. The bulk of the responsibility shouldn't fall on the narrator or the actors.
Tips.3: • The narrator can take advantage of the format by establishing tone and using scene painting.
Tips.4: • Yes and the narrators decisions including the physical reality of the space.
Tips.5: • The narrator can always jump forward in time, to a new location or rip up a page and start over. They don't have to write the story in sequential order.
Tips.6: • Focus on telling a good story rather than doing bits. Bits can have their place though.
